content:
Set\mathbf{Set}Set has an initial object, i.e. the empty set ∅\emptyset∅, and has a terminal object, i.e. the set with one element 1.1.1.

The functor
{}
K[−]:Set→VectKK[-]: \mathbf{Set\to Vect}_KK[−]:Set→VectK​
{}
sends the initial object ∅\emptyset∅ to the vector space 000 with one vector 000, i.e.
{}
K[∅]=0.K[\emptyset] = 0.K[∅]=0.
{}
However, K[−]K[-]K[−] sends the terminal object to the vector space K,K,K, i.e.
{}
K[1]=K.K[1] = K.K[1]=K.
{}
I recently learned that KKK is not the terminal object of VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ (something I should have known, but never really thought about).

Both Set\mathbf{Set}Set and VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ are bicomplete, but apparently the functor K[−]K[-]K[−] does not preserve limits (otherwise KKK would be terminal in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​) :thinking:

I think the pushout of a span
{}
A←K→BA\leftarrow K\rightarrow BA←K→B
{}
in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ is a cospan with the usual tensor product of AAA and BBB as apex, i.e.
{}
A→A⊗KB←B.A\rightarrow A\otimes_K B\leftarrow B.A→A⊗K​B←B.
{}
If so, what would be the meaning of the pushout of
{}
A←0→BA\leftarrow 0\rightarrow BA←0→B
{}
? It should be something like
{}
A→A⊗0B←BA\rightarrow A\otimes_0 B\leftarrow BA→A⊗0​B←B
{}
but I'm struggling to interpret what that would mean.

Can someone help? :pray:

Because there is a single morphism 0→V0 \rightarrow V0→V for any vector space VVV (the trivial one), whatever you put in the corner with two well typed morphisms will make the square commute. In other words, this span does not put any restriction on the cospan (except for the endpoints) which means the colimit of this span is simply a universal cospan for AAA and BBB, i.e.: a coproduct (direct sum of vector spaces).

Conclusion : A⊗0B=A⊕BA\otimes_0B = A \oplus BA⊗0​B=A⊕B
Pushouts in Vect are not tensor products, these are (quotients of) direct sums.. as Ralph is saying.

Thank you Ralph and thank you Simon :pray:

I see how the push out of span with 000 as apex is the direct sum of vector spaces.

I got it in my head that composition of cospans in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ corresponded to tensor product of bimodules :thinking:

Now I need to figure out where I went astray :thinking:

Eric Forgy said:

Both Set\mathsf{Set}Set and VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​ are bicomplete, but apparently the functor K[−]K[-]K[−] does not preserve limits (otherwise KKK would be terminal in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​) :thinking:

The functor K[−]K[-]K[−] is a left adjoint: it's left adjoint to the forgetful functor VectK→Set\mathsf{Vect}_K \to \mathsf{Set}VectK​→Set.

Left adjoints preserve all colimits. So in particular K[−]K[-]K[−] preserves the initial object, and coproducts, and pushouts.

But it's very rare for them to preserve limits. And indeed K[−]K[-]K[−] does not preserves the terminal object, or products, or pullbacks.

Right adjoints, on the other hand, preserve limits. So the forgetful functor VectK→Set\mathsf{Vect}_K \to \mathsf{Set}VectK​→Set works the other way around: it preserves terminal objects, and products, and pullbacks, but not initial objects, or coproducts, or pushouts.

All this stuff should become second nature as you get used to category theory.

Eric Forgy said:

I think the pushout of a span
{}
A←K→BA\leftarrow K\rightarrow BA←K→B
{}
in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ is a cospan with the usual tensor product of AAA and BBB as apex, i.e.
{}
A→A⊗KB←BA\rightarrow A\otimes_K B\leftarrow BA→A⊗K​B←B

You've already been informed of this, but: no.

Tensor products in VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​ are not pushouts in VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​; they are not any sort of limit or colimit in VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​. They are something new.

what would be the meaning of the pushout of
{}
A←0→BA\leftarrow 0\rightarrow BA←0→B ?

It's just A⊕BA \oplus BA⊕B. Pushing out over the initial object is the same as taking the coproduct, always!

Eric Forgy said:

I got it in my head that composition of cospans in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ corresponded to tensor product of bimodules

No. I told you all this wonderful stuff about how composing spans in a cartesian monoidal category (C,×)(\mathsf{C}, \times)(C,×) is the same as tensor product of bimodules in the cocartesian monoidal category (Cop,×)(\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}, \times)(Cop,×), and now you're applying that to (VectK,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}_K , \otimes)(VectK​,⊗), where the tensor product is not cocartesian. So you're getting nonsense.
(Remember, in (Cop,×)(\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}, \times)(Cop,×) I'm using ×\times× to refer to the product in C\mathsf{C}C, which is the coproduct in Cop\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}Cop.)

The only way to get out of the mess you got yourself in is to back out - straight back.

Tensor product of vector spaces or modules of algebras is not any sort of pushout or pullback. I told you the way of thinking that actually works, which is to treat spans in Set\mathsf{Set}Set as bimodules in Setop\mathsf{Set}^{\rm op}Setop and then map those bimodules to bimodules in (Vect,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}, \otimes)(Vect,⊗) via the monoidal functor K[−]K[-]K[−], no longer treating them as spans or cospans.
I guess if you tell someone how to cook a souffle they have to ruin a few to see why you described it so carefully.

John Baez said:

The only way to get out of the mess you got yourself in is to back out - straight back.

I keep saying this to my children but they won't listen either.
I made the same mistake Eric just made, once upon a time. The interplay between products and coproducts and tensor products is confusing at first.
I was joking and not actually referring to his understanding. The concepts are certainly confusing for me.
Yup. I tease Eric rather mercilessly, but I start defending him when other people join in teasing him.

According to Wikipedia:
{}

Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect, the category of vector spaces over a given field, can be made cocartesian monoidal with the "tensor product" given by the direct sum of vector spaces and the trivial vector space as unit.

{}
Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect is a weird category where
{}
A×B≅A⊔B≅A⊕B.A\times B\cong A\sqcup B\cong A\oplus B.A×B≅A⊔B≅A⊕B.
{}
It has pushouts and an initial object so it is finitely cocomplete. It has pullbacks and a terminal object (which is the same as initial object 000), so is also finitely complete.

Tensor product is a quotient of the product, which I believe means it is also a quotient of direct sum so I think it all actually works out.

I think it is true that the pushout
{}
A⊗0B=A⊕BA \otimes_0 B= A\oplus BA⊗0​B=A⊕B
{}
and the pushout
{}
A⊗KBA\otimes_K BA⊗K​B
{}
is a quotient of A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B in Vect.\mathbf{Vect}.Vect.
{}
John Baez said:

Eric Forgy said:

I got it in my head that composition of cospans in VectK\mathbf{Vect}_KVectK​ corresponded to tensor product of bimodules

{}
No. I told you all this wonderful stuff about how composing spans in a cartesian monoidal category (C,×)(\mathsf{C}, \times)(C,×) is the same as tensor product of bimodules in the cocartesian monoidal category (Cop,×)(\mathsf{C}^{\rm op}, \times)(Cop,×), and now you're applying that to (VectK,⊗)(\mathsf{Vect}_K , \otimes)(VectK​,⊗), where the tensor product is not cocartesian. So you're getting nonsense.

{}
Right. You told me all this wonderful stuff :raised_hands:

But since (Vect,⊕)(\mathbf{Vect},\oplus)(Vect,⊕) is cocartesian with pushout, then (Vectop,⊕)(\mathbf{Vect}^\mathsf{op},\oplus)(Vectop,⊕) is cartesian with pullback so I thought we have
{}
Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).\mathbf{Cospan(Vect,\oplus)\cong Span(Vect^\mathsf{op},\oplus) \cong Bim(Vect,\oplus)}.Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).

I think it is true that the pushout
{}
A⊗0B=A⊕BA \otimes_0 B= A\oplus BA⊗0​B=A⊕B

I don't know what ⊗0\otimes_0⊗0​ means - what do you mean by that?

and the pushout
{}
A⊗KBA\otimes_K BA⊗K​B
{}
is a quotient of A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B in Vect.\mathbf{Vect}.Vect.

No:

1) I told you earlier tonight that the tensor product A⊗KBA \otimes_K BA⊗K​B is not any sort of pushout or pullback involving AAA and BBB. Any thoughts along these lines are doomed. That's why I said "back straight out".

2) In particular, taking A=B=K4A = B = K^4A=B=K4, A⊗KB≅K16A \otimes_K B \cong K^{16}A⊗K​B≅K16 has dimension 16 so there's no way it can be a quotient of A⊕B≅K4A \oplus B \cong K^4A⊕B≅K4, which is a lower-dimensional vector space. So, it's not true that A⊗KBA\otimes_K BA⊗K​B is a quotient of A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B in Vect.\mathbf{Vect}.Vect. That's just not how tensor products work.

Eric Forgy said:

... since (Vect,⊕)(\mathbf{Vect},\oplus)(Vect,⊕) is cocartesian with pushout, then (Vectop,⊕)(\mathbf{Vect}^\mathsf{op},\oplus)(Vectop,⊕) is cartesian with pullback so I thought we have
{}
Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).\mathbf{Cospan(Vect,\oplus)\cong Span(Vect^\mathsf{op},\oplus) \cong Bim(Vect,\oplus)}.Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).
Yes, that's true.
But note, none of this has anything to do with the usual tensor product ⊗\otimes⊗ in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect.

So this is false:

the pushout
{}
A⊗KBA\otimes_K BA⊗K​B
{}
is a quotient of A⊕BA\oplus BA⊕B in Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect

and this is just meaningless by the standards of normal mathematicians:

I think it is true that the pushout
{}
A⊗0B=A⊕BA \otimes_0 B= A\oplus BA⊗0​B=A⊕B

since none of us knows what you mean by ⊗0\otimes_0⊗0​.
In both cases you're trying to connect ⊗\otimes⊗ to colimits in a way that just doesn't have any chance of working.
If you just try examples you'll quickly be disabused of such notions.

Thanks John :sweat_smile:

For sure, I've gone astray somewhere. I know that. It is just a little difficult for me to pinpoint where.

In my first comment, I said what A⊗0BA\otimes_0 BA⊗0​B was, but not very clearly. It is the object obtained from pushing out the span A←0→B,A\leftarrow 0\rightarrow B,A←0→B, which we know is coproduct. I used the tensor symbol because of the Wikipedia quote that said it was
{}

"tensor product" given by direct sum

{}
but ⊗0=⊕.\otimes_0 = \oplus.⊗0​=⊕.

If
{}
A=B=K4=K⊕K⊕K⊕KA = B = K^4 = K\oplus K\oplus K\oplus KA=B=K4=K⊕K⊕K⊕K
{}
then
{}
A⊕B=K8.A\oplus B = K^8.A⊕B=K8.
{}
I know that.

So the pushout of the span A←K→BA\leftarrow K\rightarrow BA←K→B should be A⊕KB.A\oplus_K B.A⊕K​B.

There are only so many operations that can happen in Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect so I would like to better understand how the tensor product relates to all this. I need to get to a point where I can understand a relationship (if it exists) between spans and bimodules in a way that involves actual tensor product or that beautiful knowledge I painfully acquired really isn't helpful to me, which would be a shame.

Eric Forgy said:

In my first comment, I said what A⊗0BA\otimes_0 BA⊗0​B was, but not very clearly. It is the object obtained from pushing out the span A←0→B,A\leftarrow 0\rightarrow B,A←0→B, which we know is coproduct

Yeah, the object obtained from pushing out the span A←0→B,A\leftarrow 0\rightarrow B,A←0→B, is the coproduct of AAA and BBB.

In Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect the coproduct is the direct sum, usually denoted ⊕\oplus⊕. So call it A⊕BA \oplus BA⊕B if you actually want people to understand you.

Or call it A+BA + BA+B if you want to show off the fact that you know it's the coproduct.

Or, if you want to show off the fact that it's "the object obtained from pushing out the span A←0→BA\leftarrow 0\rightarrow BA←0→B", you can call it A+0BA +_0 BA+0​B. Only a crazed category theorist would ever do this, but we'd still understand you.

The notation A⊗0BA \otimes_0 BA⊗0​B is basically just undefined crap. (Actually I can make up a meaning for it, but it's not at all useful here.)

I used the tensor symbol because of the Wikipedia quote that said it was
{}

"tensor product" given by direct sum

Yeah, but they put "tensor product" in quotes because they meant it's just a monoidal structure on Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect - the quotes basically mean "haha, just kidding, don't write it as ⊗\otimes⊗ unless you want people to think you're confused".

Btw, I have seen a few places that describe tensor product as pushout and it made sense to me, but maybe it is in a different context? For example:

https://math.stackexchange.com/questions/1548206/prove-that-tensor-product-is-pushout

[Edit: Yeah. It looks like I wanted CRing\mathbf{CRing}CRing instead of Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect I guess :face_palm: ]

There they are saying that if AAA and BBB are commutative algebras over some field KKK, the commutative algebra A⊗KBA \otimes_K BA⊗K​B is the pushout in CommAlgK\mathsf{CommAlg}_KCommAlgK​ of a certain cospan

A←K→B A \leftarrow K \to B A←K→B

That's true. But this is a pushout in CommAlgK\mathsf{CommAlg}_KCommAlgK​, not in VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​, so it's a completely different story.

By the way, for any field KKK the monoidal category (CommAlgK,⊗K)(\mathsf{CommAlg}_K, \otimes_K)(CommAlgK​,⊗K​) is cocartesian so some of the general stuff I said about cospans in cocartesian categories applies here. But (VectK,⊗K)(\mathsf{Vect}_K, \otimes_K)(VectK​,⊗K​) is not cocartesian, and that's what you were working with.

I think I see where I confused myself.

Since I got one thing right, I'll copy it here:
{}
Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).\mathbf{Cospan(Vect,\oplus)\cong Span(Vect^\mathsf{op},\oplus) \cong Bim(Vect,\oplus)}.Cospan(Vect,⊕)≅Span(Vectop,⊕)≅Bim(Vect,⊕).
{}
Among other things, this means that every vector space is a monoid object and I know monoid objects in Vect\mathbf{Vect}Vect are algebras. However, this is a monoid object in (Vect,⊕,0).(\mathbf{Vect},\oplus,0).(Vect,⊕,0). It wasn't a huge step in my mind to get from there to commutative algebras, but I went astray (surprise!).

Eric Forgy said:

... every vector space is a monoid object and I know monoid objects in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect are algebras. However, this is a monoid object in (Vect,⊕,0).(\mathsf{Vect},\oplus,0).(Vect,⊕,0).

It's good to be precise to avoid confusing oneself:

  1. Monoid objects in (VectK,⊗,K)(\mathsf{Vect}_K,\otimes,K)(VectK​,⊗,K) are algebras.

  2. Monoid objects in (VectK,⊕,0)(\mathsf{Vect}_K,\oplus,0)(VectK​,⊕,0) are something else, and they turn out to be just vector spaces.

The monoidal structure matters!!!

If a random guy walks up to you and says "monoid object in Vect\mathsf{Vect}Vect", they almost always mean "monoid object in (VectK,⊗,K)(\mathsf{Vect}_K,\otimes,K)(VectK​,⊗,K)". But you can also ask them to say which monoidal structure they're talking about.

For future reference, I think another source of confusion for me was an example of bicategory on the nLab.

If (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1) is a monoidal category, there is a corresponding bicategory BC\mathbf{B}CBC with
{}

  • One object ∙\bullet∙
  • For each object c∈Cc\in Cc∈C, a morphism [c][c][c] with composition given by monoidal product [c]∘[c′]:=[c⊗c′][c]\circ[c']:=[c\otimes c'][c]∘[c′]:=[c⊗c′]
  • For each morphism f:c→c′f:c\to c'f:c→c′ in CCC, a 2-morphism [f]:[c]→[c′].[f]:[c]\to[c'].[f]:[c]→[c′].

{}
For (Vect,⊗,K)(\mathbf{Vect},\otimes,K)(Vect,⊗,K), the composition is [S]∘[T]:=[S⊗KT].[S]\circ[T] := [S\otimes_K T].[S]∘[T]:=[S⊗K​T]. I want to relate this to spans / bimodules somehow :thinking:

If you take a bicategory, pick one object, and take all of its endomorphism 1-cells, and all 2-cells between those, its the same thing as a monoidal category, related to the fact you gave about BC\mathbf B CBC. So what do you get when you do this in the bicategory of bimodules?

Thanks Joe. This is precisely the situation I'm interested in. Super cool :blush:

In the case of Bim\mathbf{Bim}Bim, we'd pick a ring AAA and morphisms would be AAA-bimodules and 2-morphisms would be RRR-bimodule homomorphisms.

Composition of morphisms would be tensor product
{}
Ω∘Ω:=Ω⊗RΩ.\Omega \circ \Omega := \Omega\otimes_R\Omega.Ω∘Ω:=Ω⊗R​Ω.
{}
If you choose a field KKK (which is also a ring), then a KKK-bimodule is a vector space VVV and
{}
V∘V:=V⊗KV.V\circ V := V\otimes_K V.V∘V:=V⊗K​V.

Right, so in the case where we start with the bicategory

[rings, bimodules, bimodule homomorphisms]

and choose one object that happens to be a field KKK, the monoidal category we get from Joe's construction is our old friend (VectK,⊗K)(\mathsf{Vect}_K, \otimes_K)(VectK​,⊗K​).
Oh, actually that's not true!

The problem is that a (K,K)(K,K)(K,K)-bimodule is not the same as a vector space over KKK.

Vector spaces over KKK give some examples of (K,K)(K,K)(K,K)-bimodules, but not all.
The point is that whenever our ring RRR is commutative, any left RRR-module becomes a (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule in a standard way, but we don't get all (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodules this way.
A fun example is: figure out how to make the abelian group C\mathbb{C}C into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule in a nonstandard way.
So VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​ is usually just a sub-monoidal category of Joe's monoidal category, when KKK is a field.
And Joe's construction is even more interesting when the ring we pick is noncommutative.
But I don't think any of this helps Eric very much, except to give him yet another workout in categorical algebra. :muscle:
I feel so disappointed. My hero (VectK,⊗,K)(\mathbf{Vect}_K,\otimes,K)(VectK​,⊗,K) seems a lot less special now :sweat_smile:
The point is that VectK\mathsf{Vect}_KVectK​ is a category of modules of a ring, not a category of bimodules of a ring.
I thought of my counterexample pretty quickly because I've thought about doing quantum mechanics with bimodules instead of modules...
A hunch suggests that the distinction might come down to zero objects. If a KKK-bimodule has a zero object, it is a vector space?
A KKK-bimodule has scalar multiplication, so if it also has addition, it is a vector space.
I think addition requires a zero object.
https://ncatlab.org/nlab/show/additive+category

Eric Forgy said:

A hunch suggests that the distinction might come down to zero objects. If a KKK-bimodule has a zero object, it is a vector space?

It doesn't make sense to ask if a KKK-bimodule has a zero object. A category can have a zero object, not a bimodule.
I need an emoticon for "You know what I mean" :sweat_smile:
All I want to say is that if a KKK-bimodule has addition, it should also be a vector space.
Well, that's at least meaningful, but it's false. All bimodules of rings have addition, by definition.
Is everything I thought I knew about vector spaces wrong? I thought scalar multiplication that distributes over addition is enough to have a vector space :sweat_smile:
(scalar -> field)
Yes, that's true.

A vector space is a left KKK-module.

Every KKK-bimodule gives a vector space by forgetting the right KKK-module structure and only remembering the left KKK-module structure.

What I'm saying is something else: every left KKK-module gives a KKK-bimodule by defining the right module structure to equal the bimodule structure. But, not every KKK-bimodule arises this way.
So: there's a forgetfulful functor from KKK-bimodules to vector spaces, and also a functor going back the other way, but these do not form an equivalence.

I already said part of this:

John Baez said:

The point is that whenever our ring RRR is commutative, any left RRR-module becomes a (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule in a standard way, but we don't get all (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodules this way.
"Having zero objects" or "having addition" has nothing to do with this stuff.
Ok
You would understand this stuff better if you found two different ways to make C\mathbb{C}C, with its usual addition, into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule.
There's the obvious way and the less obvious way.

John Baez said:

You would understand this stuff better if you found two different ways to make C\mathbb{C}C, with its usual addition, into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule.

Yeah. I was thinking about it :thinking:
Okay. It doesn't make much sense to talk about this until after you do that....
It's like talking about the difference between lizards and salamanders before you've ever seen them.
The obvious way, I think is just that C\mathbb{C}C is already a (C,C)(\mathbb{C},\mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule with action given by +++.
Huh?
Well, C\mathbb{C}C with action given by multiplication seems too obvious and you stressed it was an abelian group :sweat_smile:
I think we're in deep trouble here.
I think you don't know what a bimodule of a ring is.
So I should just ask you "what's a bimodule of a ring?"

I'll try to answer without looking, which is dangerous :sweat_smile:

Recalling the puzzles, we start with monoid objects R,SR,SR,S in a monoidal category (C,⊗,1)(C,\otimes,1)(C,⊗,1). An (R,S)(R,S)(R,S)-bimodule is an object togoether with compatible left and right actions.
That's pretty good, at least if you know what "compatible" means.
But we were doing the classic case: bimodules of rings.
What's the monoidal category that gives this classic case?
(When you talk to algebraists and say "bimodule", you're referring to this classic case.)

I'd need to know what monoidal category has rings as monoid objects. Without looking, my guess would be Ab,\mathbf{Ab},Ab, but I've never worked this out. "Working it out" would mean checking that a bunch of intuitive diagrams commute, which I can't remember off the top of my head, but I'm fairly certain they work out here.

Good, yes, it's Ab\mathsf{Ab}Ab. So you need to know what the tensor product of abelian groups is, and then check you get a monoidal category this way, and check that monoid objects in here are exactly the same as rings, etc.
So a bimodule in this context is an abelian group A with a left action of a ring R and a right action of a ring S, obeying the "compatibility" law (which is a version of the associative law).

So my puzzle:

You would understand this stuff better if you found two different ways to make C\mathbb{C}C, with its usual addition, into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule.

says to treat C\mathbb{C}C as an abelian group in the usual way, and then find two different ways to make it into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule, where these two C\mathbb{C}C 's are being treated as a ring in the usual way.
So start by telling me one way to do this. Pick the way that's most likely to work, since you were saying some crazy stuff before.

C\mathbb{C}C is a monoid object in Ab.\mathbf{Ab}.Ab.

The most obvious way to make C\mathbb{C}C into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C},\mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule is to define the left and right actions to be multiplication, i.e. C\mathbb{C}C is already a (C,C)(\mathbb{C},\mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule just like any ring RRR is an (R,R)(R,R)(R,R)-bimodule. In this case, compatible is simply associativity.
Yes! This is what I meant by the "obvious" way to make C\mathbb{C}C into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule, since as you mention, this way works for any ring.
So the interesting part of my puzzle was to find another way to make C\mathbb{C}C into a (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C)-bimodule, which is not isomorphic to the "obvious" one.
As a hint: this other way would not work for R\mathbb{R}R; we really use the complex numbers here.
I'm drawing a blank :thinking:
Well, think about what the complex has, as a ring, that the real number doesn't. That seems like a pretty robust approach!
Note I say as a ring since this is a question about bimodules of rings. So all sorts of stuff connected to analysis is irrelevant.
Complex conjugates?
Hmm, so try using those.
I'm just throwing darts, but maybe we could define left and right actions by multiplication by the complex conjugates?
You're in the general vicinity of the dartboard. :darts:

Yes, Eric's suggestion was a bit too vague for me to tell if it's right or not... I think Reid was pointing out there are 3 things to try here.

I meant, left action
{}
z⊗m↦z∗mz\otimes m\mapsto z^* mz⊗m↦z∗m
{}
and right action
{}
m⊗z↦mz∗.m\otimes z\mapsto m z^*.m⊗z↦mz∗.
Sorry. That's a perfectly fine way to make C\mathbb{C}C into a bimodule, but it's isomorphic to the usual way! See why?

Okay, I'll say why. Your way to make C\mathbb{C}C into a bimodule is isomorphic to the usual where the left action is

z⊗m↦zmz \otimes m \mapsto zm z⊗m↦zm

and the right action is

m⊗z↦zmm \otimes z \mapsto z mm⊗z↦zm

The isomorphism is complex conjugation: m↦m∗m \mapsto m^\astm↦m∗ !

To see this, notice that if we apply your left action and then the isomorphism:

z⊗m↦z∗m↦(z∗m)∗=zm∗ z \otimes m \mapsto z^\ast m \mapsto (z^\ast m)^\ast = z m^\astz⊗m↦z∗m↦(z∗m)∗=zm∗

it's the same as applying the isomorphism to mmm and then applying the usual left action:

z⊗m↦z⊗m∗↦zm∗ z \otimes m \mapsto z \otimes m^\ast \mapsto z m^\ast z⊗m↦z⊗m∗↦zm∗

The same is true for the right action.

So, to get a really new (C,C)(\mathbb{C}, \mathbb{C})(C,C) bimodule structure on C\mathbb{C}C, we should do something like this: use the usual left action

z⊗m↦zm z \otimes m \mapsto z m z⊗m↦zm

but tweak the right action using complex conjugation:

m⊗z↦mz∗ m \otimes z \mapsto m z^\astm⊗z↦mz∗

This is not isomorphic to the usual bimodule structure: the attempted isomorphism m↦m∗m \mapsto m^\astm↦m∗ works for the right action but not the left, and the attempted isomorphism m↦mm \mapsto mm↦m works for the left action but not the right.
We could also have tweaked the left action using complex conjugation, and used the usual right action.

For what it's worth, I edited that misleading Wikipedia sentence, so it doesn't say

can be made cocartesian monoidal with the "tensor product" given by the direct sum

anymore, but

can be made cocartesian monoidal with the monoidal product given by the direct sum.

It was clearly confusing to at least one person with a PhD in a quantitative science, so ...
